content.description: Winona Ryder has fun, technical climbing on small holds. Vertical face climbing on mostly horizontal crimps leads up to a clear and exciting crux near the top. A nice addition to the canyon!
content.protection: 6 bolts.
content.location:
It is just right of

Southern Cross

.

content.description: Climb up the dark, highly featured water streak.  Clip 5 bolts to the securely wedged block of rock (the block is "on").  Clip the 6th bolt, pull cool moves over the block, and prepare for the steep section.  Gain a good stance, clip the final bolt.  Hit the "thank god" pocket up and left (crux), then veer back right on jugs to the chains.
content.protection: Quickdraws.  7 bolts to 2 bolt anchor.
content.location:
This is the obvious line right of

Raising Awareness

.

climbs.name: Wild Hops
climbs.fa: A. Scott/ original vision S. Price.  Bolted together.

content.description: A small ledge offers a rest before crux of small edges to pinch and pockets. The rest is hanging on to the anchors. Wild Hops has perfect rock and is great fun.
content.protection: 5 glue-in Fixe bolts to anchors (now with Mussy hooks). The first bolt is approximately 14 feet off the deck requiring 5.9 climbing to reach it.
content.location:
This is 100 feet past

F***in' Greenies

on the next good wall. There is a small tree right above the anchors.

Please do not climb crack in center of wall as this is where the wild hops grow, and we like to use them for brewing. Who doesn't like a good homebrew?

climbs.name: Van Gogh's
climbs.fa: A. Scott/ original vision Steve Cundy & S. Price

content.description: From the Ear up, this route offers little rest and has consistent 5.10 moves until last 10 feet. Van Gogh's is a very enjoyable route.
content.protection: 6 bolts to chains.
content.location:
10 feet left of

Wild Hops

, start on the face just right of rat turd ramp to the ear and upper wall.

content.description:
This ascends a superb, steep wave of rock tucked into an alcove on the top of the cliff. Many combos exist up and out this sweet hidden spot. Enjoy.

I have rated by average of these variations. There are plenty of easier paths and a few harder.
content.protection: A pad.
content.location: This is left of OLH finish. There is easy access to top by the trail just before First Wall.

content.description:
I haven't climbed this route yet, I am posting to remove any confusion for climbers trying to find routes.  The 5.12 rating is just a guess.  The upper half of the route looks difficult.  Anyway, climb a left-angling line, placing what looks to be very thin protection.  Transition to the upper face and clip a couple bolts to the chains.

Anyone in the know: please add more info. Route name? Grade? First ascenionist?
content.protection: Gear and bolts to chains with carabiners.
content.location:
This is between

Refuse to Suffer

and

Winning Streak

.

content.description: The crux is at the top. Climb great dinner plates to an awesome jam through the mini-roof. It is a cool route for noobs as is this entire wall.
content.protection: Over the top glue-ins.
content.location:
Trigger is 15 feet left of

Silver

.

climbs.name: Thunder Will
climbs.fa: D. Huwe/ original vision S. Price & D. Huwe

content.description: A bouldery crux start leads to a cruiser mid-section, capped with another steep crux at the top. This is a great first lead.
content.protection: 6 glue-in bolts to over the top anchors.
content.location:
Thunder Will is left of

Lightning Crashes

.

content.description: This is an excellent, sustained 5.9 face climb.  The route gives you a taste of the style of climbing on the high quality rock of Hops Wall.
content.protection: Quickdraws, 5 bolts to 2 bolt anchor with chains and lowering carabiners.
content.location: This is the farthest right route on Hops Wall.

content.description: The whole thing is a crux, off balance all the way.
content.protection:
It shares bolts with

Black

. Stay right of the bolts.

content.description: Climb up a short pedestal, and then move on to the face. Clip three bolts, and then work through the small roof crux. The crux is much easier once you find all of the holds. Once above the roof, enjoy off vertical edging and sidepulls to the top, and arrive at a two bolt anchor with chains and rap rings. Please do not toprope through the rap rings.
content.protection: 10 draws total, including the anchor.
content.location:
This route is just right of

Emotionally Involved

. From the base of Hops Wall, walk far left past

Raising Awareness

, and continue past

Melliodious

, follow the climber's trail down and then up and around to the base of the route. Locate the pedestal and the first bolt just about 6’ off the ground.

climbs.name: Southern Cross
climbs.fa: A. Scott/ original vision Jason & Wayne

content.description:
The crux is the last move on the route. There are 5.10 thin edges and pockets until the last 10 feet. Southern Cross flows like a great boulder problem.

Eds. Per

Parachute Adams

: the name of this route refers to the constellation in the southern hemisphere called the Southern Cross, the equivalent of the Big Dipper in the northern hemisphere.
content.protection: 4 (5?) bolts to chains (now with Mussy hooks).
content.location:
This is 100 feet downstream from

November Reign

on a dirt ledge above trail, right of a chocolate corner on smooth, black wall.

content.description: Newbies and young ones will enjoy this short slab, a great spot to work on your friction skills.  For a challenge, tape a of tennis ball to each hand so they can only be used for balance, it will do wonders for your footwork.
content.protection: Single bolt.
content.location: Hike in past the first bolted route on the right and then look for the short slab on the left.  Flake your rope out OFF the trail and be sure to leave room for passing hikers, bikers, and horses.

content.description:
The crux depends on which local you ask. I think the last 15 feet are the crux while others feel the roof start is it. Climb it and decide for yourself.

Smokin' Stems is a beautiful, right-facing corner with great rock and moves. As the name suggests, it has lots of stemming. The FA was done to the top before the chains.
content.protection: There is a fixed piton in roof at start, then use small to medium cams & stoppers to chain anchors. The piton was placed during an aid ascent circa 1999.
content.location:
This is 150 feet past

Chocolate Corner

, just left of ascent/descent gully and very obvious from trail. The area at bottom of the climb is known as base camp. It is a great place to get out of the rain.

content.description:
This shares the start with

Smokin' Stems

and busts out right onto a wild traverse! Tip toe across the exposed roof, and then go straight up through some classic Piedra jugs. The crux is 11 b/c in the crack, and the face goes at sustained 10b/c.

Be aware that this route is a lil spicy by nature, and those not comfortable at the grade should take caution. I didn't want to crowd the existing climb

Black Magic Spell

with bolts, so there is a slight runout on easy terrain getting to the second bolt. The runout looks a lot worse from the ground compared to how it climbs.

It is best cleaned by following. Followers, watch the second bolt swing.
content.protection: Clip the piton, cams 0.75-2, 7 bolts, and Mussy hook anchors.

content.description: The crux is at the top. It has good moves and is a great place to introduce noobs to the sport. If you are a 5.7 leader, you will step up your game for this one.
content.protection:
5 bolts to over the top glue ins.

Per

scout Richardson

: 5 bolts.
content.location:
Start 20 feet left of

Black Beauty

.

content.description:
This is the farthest left route in this area.  It's a little fragile and dirty feeling still, but it is very sustained and the overall rock quality is good for the area.  It should clean up nicely.

We decided to do this route because the base and the first one-third of the route were in the shade.  It turned out to be pretty good.

Per

Pullhard

: this is a good face climb on orange colored rock. The crux is 3/4 of the way up. It is cleaner and better than Rave Mode, which is on the right side of the wall.

Eds. this is a combination of 2 submissions put onto the 1st submission's page to avoid confusion.
content.protection: Seven protection bolts to a two-bolt anchor with chains.
content.location:
Currently this is the [second] farthest left route in this area.  It is located about 50 yards to the left of "

Full Body Brace

".  Bushwhack about 50 yards uphill from the trail to the base of the wall.  As of 2013-09-07, there is another red-tagged route immediately to the right of this route.

Per

Pullhard

: do a steep hike up to the left side of Mod Wall. There is a good belay stance once you get there.

content.description: This is a fun, steep, quality climb.  Take the left arm of the "Y" formation.  Continue up and left to the bulge.  Pull on excellent edges and pockets to the chains.
content.protection: Quickdraws. 6 bolts to 2 bolt chain anchor with lowering carabiners.
content.location:
It is between

Different Strokes

and

Winning Streak

.

content.description: This is good for the grade, sustained 5.8 climbing.  Climb an intermittent seam and large flakes to the chains.
content.protection: Quickdraws.  5 bolts to 2 bolt anchor with chains.
content.location:
Take the main trail past

Emotionally Involved

.  Steep but short hike up to the wall.  Find a flat belay stance at the base of the climb.

content.description: This is one of the better, longer, and more difficult routes in the canyon.  Bouldery start, then make some balance and delicate moves.  Enjoy the large flake, and then get a rest for the steeper and more sustained climbing above.
content.protection: Quickdraws, 8 bolts to 2 bolt chain anchors.
content.location:
Left of

Winning Streak

.

content.description: Practice Wall has a crux midway and another again at the top.
content.protection: Toprope with over the top glue-ins (formerly with chains, now with Mussy hooks).
content.location: It is at the left end of the main traverse wall above Otter Beach.

content.description: Follow a tiny, left-facing corner. A hard crux off the ground leads to a more moderate climbing with good clips.
content.protection: Bolts.
content.location:
This is right of

Winona Ryder

.

content.description: Do a bushy start. Continue on jugs and dinner plates up a blunt arête.
content.protection: I have only done this solo. It would be great cleaned and bolted if anyone is up to it.
content.location:
It is just left of

Deuce

.

climbs.name: November Reign
climbs.fa: S. Price/ original vision Dean Huwe & S. Price

content.description:
November Reign is very similar to

Thunder Will

, only harder. A balancy start leads to a cruiser mid-section then goes back to a steep crux. In my opinion, using the crack/tree at start makes this a lot easier and takes away from the spirit of the climb. Step up! The only thing that keeps this route from 4 stars is the middle section, which is out of character with the two cruxes. November Reign is a worthy climb anyway.
content.protection: 6 bolts to over the top anchors.
content.location:
November Reign is 15 feet left of

Thunder Will

. Please do not grab the tree in the crack.

content.description: Noodle Wall is a toprope located at Otter Beach. It is also done as a highball boulder problem. The crux is at start.
content.protection: Toprope off the tree.
content.location: It is on the river side of trail opposite main traverse. There is a huge tree growing out of top. Anchor off the tree to TR. It is a great place to camp. Pack out all your trash, and expect company on busy weekends.

content.description: The crux is 1/3 the way up in a bulge. Stemming out right makes this a lot easier.
content.protection: Over the top glueins.
content.location:
Nick & Todd is left of

Practice Wall

.

content.description:
Starts on the ground at

Taster's Choice

, but moves left to the first bolt. The route climbs slightly right of the 2nd & 3rd bolts to gain the small flake ledge (but not way right on the flake itself). It finishes up the left side of the rounded arete towards the top.
content.protection: 4 bolts to chains.
content.location:
This is just left of

Taster's Choice

& about 20 feet right of

Mild Hops

.

content.description:
Moman is a seriously overhanging arete left of

Noodle Wall

looking  at river. It leans towards the river. Begin with a sit start to a midway crux on thin pockets and scummy heelhooks.
content.protection: Pad.
content.location: Moman lies at the upstream end of Otter Beach. Otter Beach is a great place to camp. Pack out all your trash please, and expect company on busy weekends.

content.description: This is another great Piedra face climb on steep, solid edges. It has pretty technical movement on dead vertical rock. That said you seem to be able to get a rest after each section, so it never gets that pumpy. This is a great warm-up for the other routes around it but also a must do route in general.
content.protection: 6 bolts to lowering anchors (now with Mussy hooks).
content.location: This is just right of the "Hops". Start on a black face and climb into the orange/blonde rock up high.

content.description: Do some easy face climbing to a ledge, and clip the high first bolt. Then move up and right on positive crimps and fat jugs, and surf the arete to the chains. The climbing is steep and fun, but the rock quality on this one is a little lesser than some of its neighbors, so go easy on some of the flakes.
content.protection: Bolts. You need an alpine draw for one of the bolts under the roof.
content.location:
A little bit left of the main area and 50 feet right of

Emotionally Involved

.

content.description: Moving into the mini cave is the crux. This traverse offers more climbing than many of the routes here.
content.protection: Pad.
content.location:
Start at base of the route

Golden Seam

then go right through the mini-cave to join

Main Traverse

.

content.description: This is a nice low traverse that is devoid of poision ivy.  It is a good way to get a pump on when alone.
content.location: About 200 yards after entering the area, the trail rises and briefly levels out before again droping a little.  There is a 20 foot high clean wall that has a chimney/cleft on its left.  This is the left end of the traverse.  The right edge is where the briars begin to get thick.

climbs.name: Lightning Crashes
climbs.fa: no one remembers, original vision Jason & Wayne

content.description: The crux is 1/3 the way up in a shallow corner. This route was also 5.9 when the block across trail from route came out while being climbed. The crux is through the same section now climbing obviously better rock. A variety of holds and moves makes this the must do 5.9 in PR.
content.protection: 7 glue-in bolts. There are glue-in anchors (now with Mussy hooks) on the face and over the top as well. Use the ones over the top.
content.location:
Lightning Crashes is 25 feet left of

Black

.

content.description: This is a right-facing corner up great rock following hands to layback crack, 45 feet.
content.protection: Bring up to size 2 cam standard rack. Glue in anchors.
content.location:
It starts 75 feet left of

Raising Awareness

. Scramble/bushwhack up to start under black slab.

climbs.name: Immediate Unreality
climbs.fa: "Parachute Adams", bolted by Nicholas Ryan Valoff

content.description: Increasingly difficult moves lead to a strange mantle between the second and third bolt using a glassy, razor-sharp crimp and a series of seemingly useless "right-hand" holds. The crux continues briefly past the third bolt with a sick deadpoint followed by a decent rest and another 12- mantel that is harder than it looks.
content.protection: Bolts.
content.location:
This route is located to the left of the

5.8 warm-up

. It follows the obvious black and white stripes up the overhanging portion of this wall.

climbs.name: I & Eye
climbs.fa: A. Scott  with Dean Huwe, original vision: Steve Cundy

content.description:
The crux is on the arete. From a handmatch in the eye feature, pull onto arete to find a mixed bag of crimps, pockets, and slopers. Finish up slab to shared anchor with

Hollow Excuse

. It is good, clean air if you blow the crux.
content.protection:
7 bolts to chains. The last bolt is shared with

Hollow Excuse

.
content.location:
I & Eye is the obvious arete left of

Van Gogh's

.

content.description: This horizontal double arete is a must do. Sit start to incuts and funky toe/heelhooks up to prow finish.
content.protection: Pad.
content.location: It lies at the downstream end of Otter Beach.

content.description: Climb big edges through the first 3 bolts.  Clip the 4th bolt, get a rest, then climb the crux on small holds.  The route lets up some but is fairly sustained to the last bolt.  Obviously the crack is off route, but there are some face holds close to the crack that might help toward the top of the climb.
content.protection: Quickdraws, 8 bolts to 2 bolt anchor with chains (now with Mussy hooks).
content.location:
This is between

Wild Hops

and the hops vines.

climbs.name: Hollow Excuse
climbs.fa: A. Scott/ original vision S. Price

content.description: Layback to a great, one finger pocket and move into crux section. I love this crux.
content.protection:
5 bolts to chains. The last bolt is shared with

I & Eye

.
content.location:
Hollow Excuse is left of

I & Eye

in alcove known as The Y.

content.description:
Groomed Gumby has fun, classic Piedra style climbing with thoughtful sections throughout.

The first 15’ will clean up nicely with time & traffic.

Your belayer should wear a helmet while the route gets cleaned up.
content.protection: 8 bolts and a 2 bolt anchor with steel lowering carabiners.
content.location:
The very next route 30’ left of

Smokin' Stems

and immediately right of

F***in' Greenies

.

content.description:
There are various problems and variations on this overhanging wall.  The huge tree makes topping out impossible. Ratings vary depending on what you do, but V5 is probably a good average. Top and drop when you reach tangle of branches.

2017 update: the tree has fallen down opening the upper wall. Please do not bolt this wall. I will set a bomber TR anchor.
content.protection: A pad.
content.location:
It lies between

Noodle Wall

amd

Moman

at Otter Beach. It is a great place to camp if you want to spend the night in canyon. There is a good chance of seeing otters early or late if you are not too noisy.

content.description:
As you enter the canyon, the walls meet the trail.  At the first great swimming hole, look up and right to a brown face with shiny bolts, 7 total.  The runout to the first bolt was demanding climbing on small edges.  Then more of the same but bigger as you went up.

Per ??: the crux start can be easily bypassed by short traverse in from right dropping the rating to 5.10+.
content.protection: 7 draws.
content.location: Walk along the trail downstream to the canyon proper. Just before the huge boulder at the water's edge, look up and right.

content.description: The first 3/4ths of route are 5.6 cruiser. The last 15 feet are a great V1 boulder problem.
content.protection: Over the top glue-ins.
content.location:
Giggin is 20 feet left of

November Reign

.

content.description:
This trad climb has plenty of face holds and edges.  The route also features good hand jams and some stemming.

A pocketed face gets you started in the crack, which takes gear well.  Pull through the easily protected crux - a short, steep section. Cruise to the top using the crack and face.  The crack widens toward the top; finish on the face to the right.

Belay the second up and remember to enjoy the views over at the edge of the prow.
content.protection: Cams: mostly hands and big hands.  If you're comfortable at the grade, nothing bigger than BD #4.  A small piece might help near the start.
content.location:
It is near the farthest visible prow on the lower west cliff band.  Use the same approach as for the other lower west climbs, but take the right fork in the trail 20 yards before First Wall.  It is a 10-15 minute hike from here, following the rim of the canyon.

Look for the chained anchor (N 37 24.891'  W 107 12.048').  If the cliff below disappears, you have hiked past the climb.  Rack up, rap from the chains, then climb it back out to the top.  Or, hike down just past the prow to access the bottom.  There is some scree and oak brush if you hike, but it can easily be done.

Note: there are two cracks in this area.  The one easiest to see from the rim is dirty and full of choss; this is not the route.  The one to climb is to the climber's left.  It is difficult to see from the rim, but it is obvious at the base of the climb.

content.description: The crux is getting to first bolt. There are big holds for rest of route, but it is pumpy.
content.protection: 5 bolts to anchor (now with chains).
content.location: This is the first route in canyon. Walkoff or lower.

climbs.name: F***in' Greenies
climbs.fa: A. Scott/ original vision D. Huwe

content.description: The crux is near the top. Difficulty progresses the higher you go starting at about 5.7. This is one of the more enjoyable routes in the canyon. It has beautiful black and orange streaked rock. It is a great first lead of the grade or warmup for those who climb at a higher level. The first bolt is easy to skip.
content.protection: 9 glue-in Fixe bolts to chains.
content.location:
F***in' Greenies is 20 feet left of

Smokin' Stems

starting on small ledge with a large tree on it.

content.description: This is a long, fun climb.  Start with a leftward traverse, then continue up the face.  Finish on a blunt arete and big ledges to the chains.  The crux moves are halfway up.
content.protection: Quickdraws.  10 bolts to 2 bolt anchor with chains.
content.location:
Take the foot path along the wall, past

Raising Awareness

.  The route is on the tall, black wall.

content.description:
Scramble up the 5.6 ramp for 10’. Clip the first bolt, and cruise up the off vertical face to the 5th bolt. Dance through the crux on thoughtful footwork, clip bolt 6 and cruise once again to the top. Arrive at a 2 bolt anchor with rap rings. Please do not toprope through the rap rings.

Note: there is natural protection to be had on the 5.6 ramp start or even a possible cam placement, but it really is easy climbing.

The 5th bolt is intentionally a little farther left on the face, to avoid having the rope & quickdraw getting twisted up in your feet during the crux section.

The anchor for Dirty Dancing also works really well for

Jammers Kant

, as it keeps the rope out of the crack and is much better than climbing up the dirty corner to the bolts way over the top. You probably just want to leave some directionals for the follower.
content.protection: 6 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor with rap rings.
content.location:
From the base of Hops Wall, walk left past

Raising Awareness

, and continue on the climber's trail through the high grass. When you arrive at the wall, you’ll be at the bottom of

Emotionally Involved

. Continue up and past

The Sweet Spot

and

Jammers Kant

, and look straight up at Dirty Dancing.

content.description: The first 12 feet are doable in flipflops. The rest of the route makes up for it. It follows the right arm of what is locally known as the Y.
content.protection: 5 black bolts and anchors over the top.
content.location:
This is left of

Hollow Excuse

. See the photo for

Hollow Excuse

.

content.description: This route has a trad start to bolted face. The crux is about 2/3 the way up on thin edges.
content.protection: Medium cams to 5 bolts.
content.location:
It is just left of

First Wall

. Walk or lower off.

content.description: The crux is getting on to ledge near top. It is usually dirty as top of corner acts like a funnel for debris above. Too bad as the climbing is quality.
content.protection: Standard trad rack. Glue-in Fixe anchors at top.
content.location:
Chocolate Corner is left of

Southern Cross

in an obvious corner. It has chocolate colored rock, hence the name.

content.description:
Good warm-up moves on positive holds off the ground lead to a VERY reachy dihedral section. Above this, save some gas for the powerful finish MOOOO-VES. - YEE-HAW!! -

This wall faces north, so it's usually shaded during the hot morning hours of summer. It is a pretty good warm-up route though it requires power if you're not tall.
content.protection: 5 bolts to lowering anchors (now with Mussy hooks).
content.location:
This is 20 feet left of

Chocolate Corner

.

content.description:
This is a mixed gear route.  Begin the climb at "

Smokin' Stems

."  Clip a piton and place gear to protect the steep start, then follow the bolts up and right.  It is good climbing on a beautiful, black face.
content.protection: Piton, a couple cams, and perhaps a nut protect the start before the first bolt. 7 bolts to 2 bolt anchor (now with Mussy hooks). It is probably best to clean the route on toprope, then rap from chains (now lower from Mussy hooks).
content.location:
See the photo to the right and beta photo for "

Smokin' Stems

."

content.description: The crux is at 1/3 height.  Black Beauty is thin for the grade at its crux but cruiser for upper 2/3rds.
content.protection:
5 or 6 bolts to an anchor.

Per

Andy Bandos

: the anchors are placed on top of the wall. The anchors consist of just bolt hangers and no chains or carabiners from which to lower.
content.location:
It is 40 feet left of

November Reign

on a black ramp.

content.description:
The route is left of the 11c/d,

Tan

, in a dihedral. Climb the right edge of the wall on great overhanging holds to start.  Big fun.
content.protection: 5 bolts and an anchor with chains (Fixe hangers) (now with Mussy hooks).
content.location: Walk downstream from the bridge until the walls rise above you, look to the right when the big boulders are found along the trail.
